messages.subject: Announcing NEW and Exciting Website from the Mantis Dude
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I was waiting to announce this since I was expecting 1 more tsuba to come in, but I can t wait anymore.  I took a week of playing and made myself a
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

I was waiting to announce this since I was expecting 1
more tsuba to come in, but I can't wait anymore. I
took a week of playing and made myself a website. The
website is of my collection, including information on
symbolism of the praying mantis in fittings.

www.freewebs.com/kamakiriken/index.htm

Please feel free to comment, add, help, etc with
anything. Milt didn't like the color scheme, but I
ignored that, however I was surprised to learn I was
using green since I thought it was grey (a little
color blind)

I am kind of proud of myself, since inspite of having
no programs to edit pictures other than XEview and
microsoft paint, and no website programs, I was able
to put this together with basic knowledge of html. I
taught myself html 8 years ago, but really never used
it. It was somewhat fun to go through my collection
and document my pieces. I had already took pictures
for my records so I had the pictures of my items.
Just had to upload it. Lots of free stuff out there
to use on the internet.

Hope you enjoy it and any help or additional
information would be helpful, just email me. Thanks
to previewers for their comments.

Thanks for looking (in advance).
Ken "THE MANTIS DUDE"

__________________________________________________
Do You Yahoo!?

http://mail.yahoo.com

Interesting, Are these classified as shiirimono? It
still seems that this tsuba has a lot of handiwork in

Thanks,
Ken

> The blade in question was appraised in London and given probable
> attribution as an Oei-Bizen tachi in the form of the late Heian period,
> possibly to one of the "Oei no San Mitsu"

> hamon is a very narrow suguha which continues through the boshi and

> blade is not in full polish but good condition with no rust or fatal

messages.subject: Lost / Stolen Sword
messages.msgSnippet: All, posted from the NMB, if you feel up to passing this on to another forum, please do. cheers Rich Turner Hi All, I am desperately seeking help to recover a
messages.messageBody:
All, posted from the NMB, if you feel up to passing this on to another
forum, please do.

cheers

Rich Turner


Hi All, I am desperately seeking help to recover a sword that went
missing on Monday 06 June on a flight between London and New York (JFK).
The blade in question was appraised in London and given probable
attribution as an Oei-Bizen tachi in the form of the late Heian period,
possibly to one of the "Oei no San Mitsu"

The blade measures 66 cm with 2.7 cm koshi sori and ko-kissaki. The
hamon is a very narrow suguha which continues through the boshi and
finishes in a small kaeri. The blade is suriage with a mumei nakago
showing the sori of the original length and with three mekugiana. The
blade is not in full polish but good condition with no rust or fatal
flaws. It does have two very slight bends through the monouchi area.
Photos available at the following link.

If anyone, particularly in and around London or NY, hears of or sees a
blade of this desription I would really appreciate hearing from you.

Thanks, p+++ed off in Chile.

Link: http://www.villagephotos.com/pubbrowse.asp?folder_id=1672490

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb/forum/index.php?action=display&forumid=1&msgid=9206


--
*Richard Turner - Nihonto Message Board*
/for the discussion of all things Nihonto./
www.nihontomessageboard.com <http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb/>



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mino Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Kenneth, The tsuba is a Nagoya-mono from Owari, as the metal is brown and not true shakudo it is from the later period, one feature commonly found on Nagoya
messages.messageBody:
Hi Kenneth,
The tsuba is a Nagoya-mono from Owari, as the metal is brown and not true shakudo it is from the later period, one feature commonly found on Nagoya work are the 4 'chips', 2 each out of the sides of the nakago-ana at the top and bottom .

The tsuba might be from a yari blade mounted as a tanto or wakizashi.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Kenneth Wilson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, June 07, 2006 5:53 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mino Tsuba

Thanks
Ken aka "the mantis dude"

> Hi all,
>
> Picked this up from Germany. It is a beautiful Mino
> Shakudo Tsuba. I believe the kogai ana is filled
> with
> copper. It has nice nanako. The edge is completely
> filled with leaves and flowers,etc. The only really
> weird thing is that the seppa-dai must have be put
> on
> a pole weapon or something. It has notches put in
> and
> the nakaga ana has been widened. Questions, where
> would you classify this? I was thinking mid-edo,
> but
> what would you look for in ko-mino work? I have
> been
> looking for a piece like this for a long time and I
> think I did well on the purchase. Comments please
> (good and bad).
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mino Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Mantis Dude, I think it looks more like having been used as a doorknob escutcheon in Germany!!  Note the circular impression above the hole where it was
messages.messageBody:
Mantis Dude,

I think it looks more like having been used as a doorknob escutcheon in Germany!! Note the circular impression above the "hole" where it was possibly mounted. I heard somewhere years ago that in Paris many tsuba were used in this way, complete with nail holes where they were fixed to doors. A mate of mine has a beautiful shibuichi wakizashi tsuba with a similar, but smaller hole. It was fitted to an umbrella...

Regards,

Batman Dude.

From: Kenneth Wilson

messages.subject: Mino Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, Picked this up from Germany.  It is a beautiful Mino Shakudo Tsuba.  I believe the kogai ana is filled with copper.  It has nice nanako.  The edge is
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

Picked this up from Germany. It is a beautiful Mino
Shakudo Tsuba. I believe the kogai ana is filled with
copper. It has nice nanako. The edge is completely
filled with leaves and flowers,etc. The only really
weird thing is that the seppa-dai must have be put on
a pole weapon or something. It has notches put in and
the nakaga ana has been widened. Questions, where
would you classify this? I was thinking mid-edo, but
what would you look for in ko-mino work? I have been
looking for a piece like this for a long time and I
think I did well on the purchase. Comments please
(good and bad).

http://w25.photobucket.com/widgets/dynamicflash.php?featuretype=bucketstrip&featurename=Minotsuba&pa=/c52/kamakiri/Mino/
Double click on scrolling picture to view more
detailed photo. Just playing with internet tools.

Thanks.
Ken

messages.msgSnippet: Although it s not really mine I ve always liked it and it s good to know about the onlay and the attribution.   These early school pieces sort of run
messages.messageBody:
Although it's not really 'mine' I've always liked it and it's good to
know about the onlay and the attribution. These early school pieces
sort of run together sometimes. Thanks much Alan!

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Alan Bale" <abale@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Pete,
> I have just looked at your kozuka, this is not suri-hegashi gilding
but uttori-zogan that has worn through showing the typical 'holes' in
the inlay (or more properly 'overlay'), the last fruit is only just
showing the wear, some leaves are worn also, uttori zogan would not
have a hole in the top. The kozuka looks like 16th century Mino Goto,
The early Goto did not use suri-hegashi gilding.
> Alan
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Post dated Post Update (LOL)
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Pete, I have just looked at your kozuka, this is not suri-hegashi gilding but uttori-zogan that has worn through showing the typical holes in the inlay
messages.messageBody:
Hi Pete,
I have just looked at your kozuka, this is not suri-hegashi gilding but uttori-zogan that has worn through showing the typical 'holes' in the inlay (or more properly 'overlay'), the last fruit is only just showing the wear, some leaves are worn also, uttori zogan would not have a hole in the top. The kozuka looks like 16th century Mino Goto, The early Goto did not use suri-hegashi gilding.
Alan



----- Original Message -----
From: klepet33319
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, May 30, 2006 2:09 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Post dated Post Update (LOL)


This kozuka is a good example of this type of finishing technique:

http://nihonto.com/11.10.02.html

Fred even comments on it in the write-up. Ezo pieces used a
different application technique for the gold but same difference.

messages.subject: Re: Post dated Post Update (LOL)
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Alan and thanks for the information on Mrs. Schneidman.  I will have to look into finding the catalog. I just came upon this information today and it
messages.messageBody:
Hi Alan and thanks for the information on Mrs. Schneidman. I will
have to look into finding the catalog.
I just came upon this information today and it coincides with your
question. It is from 'Kodogu' pg. 20, by Gunther Heckmann

'Until a few years ago it was generally agreed that sword decorations
of this sort were produced by the Ainu, the native inhabitants of
Japan's northern island Ezo, which is nowadays called Hokkaido. For
this reason these sort of objects are usually called Ezo koshirae.
Because of the fact that the Ainu did not have a deep knowledge of
metal processing, we should rather use the term Shoki Kinko, 'the
first kinko period', for this type of work. Other ideas about the
origin of these objects can be oriented from the beginnings of the
fire gilding technique in China, during the T'ang dynesty (618-906),
and the possible use of imported Chinese bronze for the production of
sword decoration.
The basic metal used for these objects is different from the metal
usually used for sword decoration. An examination of the metal
content of this pair of menuki was performed in April 1996, by Prof.
Dr. Richter of the Institut fur technologie der Malerei, in
Stuttgart, using LASER micro spectral analysis and atomic absorption
spectral anallysis. The main componenets of the metal in this
object are 70% copper, 25% silver, and the remaining 5% shows traces
of lead, gold, mercury iron, calcium magnesium, aluninum, and
silicon. The gold and mercury derive from the fire gilding. The
other contents can be taced to the partially refined copper. An
alloy of 25% silver and 75% copper is often used for Japanese sword
decoration and is called oborogin. With a higher percentage of
silver to copper the alloy is called rogin or more commonly
shibuichi. For the outome of the alloy, it is important to know that
when silver is added to copper in these quantities, it tends to rise
to the surface, which is the reason for the silvery appearance of the
Shoki Kinko pieces. It is not clear yet why especially this alloy
was used for sword decoration at such an early time. These objects
are mostly deated from the early to middle Muromachi period (1400 -
1450), sometimes even earlier. Shibuichi was always considered to be
a metal of the Edo period, but the date of origin of oborogin is
unknown. Further analyses of the so coalled Shoki Kinko decarations
are necessary before any conclusion can be made about the components
of these sword fittings. With this first analyses an important and
stimulating step was made towards further studies of this subject.

Buttweiler in his writing stated he felt the dark color under the
gilding may have been due to the effect of mercury on the copper in
combination with the gold creating a layer of 'shakudo' and this
effect may have led t it's discovery as an alloy. (This gilding was
post probably done by making a slurry paste of gold filings and
mercury and then heat evaporating the mercury leaving the gold layer).

Note: link to picture of Ezo fitting used in the book:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/7936?b=2



-- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Alan Bale" <abale@...> wrote:
>
> Regarding Ezo menuki I think that these were not suri-hegashi inlay
but genuinely worn pieces. Something that has puzzled me for a long
time is that many Ezo menuki I have seen have a silvery metal base
not unlike shibuichi but the books always say 'yamagane', but I have
never seen this silvery metal on anything other than Ezo items.
> Alan
>
>
> SPONSORED LINKS Buy fine art Japanese translation Japanese
incense
> Fine art inkjet paper Fine art printing Fine art
appraisal

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Post dated Post Update (LOL)
messages.msgSnippet: Regarding Ezo menuki I think that these were not suri-hegashi inlay but genuinely worn pieces. Something that has puzzled me for a long time is that many Ezo
messages.messageBody:
Regarding Ezo menuki I think that these were not suri-hegashi inlay but genuinely worn pieces. Something that has puzzled me for a long time is that many Ezo menuki I have seen have a silvery metal base not unlike shibuichi but the books always say 'yamagane', but I have never seen this silvery metal on anything other than Ezo items.
Alan
----- Original Message -----
From: klepet33319
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, May 30, 2006 1:03 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Post dated Post Update (LOL)


Hi Barry,
It's an interesting study to be sure although I'm not aware of
too much available literature to 'study'. The 'Bushido' magazines
from Robert Benson (1980's) had a lot of great information, and the
1976 Tai Kai from San Francisco book has a lot of information also (I
believe there's a copy at Bridge of Dreams). They show up on Ebay
from time to time also.
What I was referring to with the kozuka was the effect of
removing of gold revealing the substrate for effent, which you can
see better there than on the menuki where there is definatley wear
involved also. Ezo menuki were fabricated on a positive mould from
thin copper sheet, then the gold was applied using a mercury
technique (probably heat evaporation), then burnished with a needle
to get the effect. Uttori by definition is attachment of the inly
around the edges only, although I would imagine there is some form of
burnishing or other form of adhesion involved as well. As far as the
wear to the menuki, hell, I hope I look that good when I'm that old!

Pete

PS: I have a feeling they are older than Edo due to the posts both
being open -- possibly Jim would know?











--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@...>
wrote:
>
> I have been aware for a few years that the deliberate rubbing of
gold to look
> worn is a well-established part of the metal workers' repetoire. I
believe it
> is meant to impart an "antique" look, or maybe it's that "wabi-
sabi" serpent
> rearing its ugly head again. Either way, if an item looks to be of
good quality
> and in good condition AND the gold looks worn, then it is more
likely to be a
> deliberate effect and original and NOT a "condition problem". I
would sure like
> to know more about this.
>
> Regards,
>
> Barry Thomas.
>

involved also. Ezo menuki were fabricated on a positive mould from
thin copper sheet, then the gold was applied using a mercury
technique (probably heat evaporation), then burnished with a needle
to get the effect. Uttori by definition is attachment of the inly
around the edges only, although I would imagine there is some form of
burnishing or other form of adhesion involved as well. As far as the
wear to the menuki, hell, I hope I look that good when I'm that old!

Pete

messages.subject: Post dated Post Update (LOL)
messages.msgSnippet: http://www.aoi-art.com/fittings/menuki/itaku04.html These would seem to confirm what Mr. Buttweiler said about interim menuki having two female posts which
messages.messageBody:
http://www.aoi-art.com/fittings/menuki/itaku04.html

These would seem to confirm what Mr. Buttweiler said about interim
menuki having two female posts which would fit onto a mekugi from both
sides.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Post dated Post Update (LOL)
messages.msgSnippet: I have been aware for a few years that the deliberate rubbing of gold to look worn is a well-established part of the metal workers repetoire.  I believe it is
messages.messageBody:
I have been aware for a few years that the deliberate rubbing of gold to look
worn is a well-established part of the metal workers' repetoire. I believe it
is meant to impart an "antique" look, or maybe it's that "wabi-sabi" serpent
rearing its ugly head again. Either way, if an item looks to be of good quality
and in good condition AND the gold looks worn, then it is more likely to be a
deliberate effect and original and NOT a "condition problem". I would sure like
to know more about this.

Regards,

Barry Thomas.
